Learning the Greek alphabet together as a couple is one of the most rewarding first steps in your language journey. While the script may look unfamiliar at first, you will be surprised how quickly you can master it when you practice together. The Greek alphabet has only 24 letters, and many of them will feel familiar once you understand the sounds they represent.

This guide will take you through every letter, with pronunciation tips, romantic vocabulary to practice, and exercises designed for couples learning together.

## Why Learn the Greek Alphabet First?

Before diving in, understand why mastering the Greek alphabet is essential:

1. **Greek uses a unique script** - Unlike Spanish or French, you cannot simply read Greek using English letters
2. **Transliteration is inconsistent** - Different sources spell Greek words differently in English letters
3. **It unlocks authentic learning** - Reading Greek script opens doors to signs, menus, and love notes from your partner
4. **It is easier than you think** - Many Greek letters look or sound similar to English ones

<CultureTip title="The Birthplace of the Alphabet" flag="ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡·">
The Greek alphabet, developed around 800 BCE, was the first to include vowels and is the ancestor of the Latin alphabet we use in English. When you learn Greek letters, you are connecting with over 2,800 years of written history.
</CultureTip>

## The Greek Alphabet: All 24 Letters

Let us break down the alphabet into manageable groups. Practice each group together before moving on.

### Group 1: Familiar Friends (Letters That Look and Sound Similar to English)

These letters will feel comfortable right away:

| Greek | Name | Pronunciation | English Equivalent |
|-------|------|---------------|-------------------|
| **A Î±** | Alpha | AHL-fah | A as in "father" |
| **E Îµ** | Epsilon | EHP-see-lon | E as in "pet" |
| **I Î¹** | Iota | YOH-tah | I as in "machine" |
| **K Îº** | Kappa | KAH-pah | K as in "key" |
| **M Î¼** | Mi | mee | M as in "mother" |
| **N Î½** | Ni | nee | N as in "no" |
| **O Î¿** | Omicron | OH-mee-kron | O as in "hot" |
| **T Ï„** | Tau | taf | T as in "top" |
| **Z Î¶** | Zeta | ZEE-tah | Z as in "zoo" |

  translation="mom"
  pronunciation="mah-MAH"
  example="Î— Î¼Î±Î¼Î¬ Î¼Î¿Ï… ÎµÎ¯Î½Î±Î¹ Ï…Ï€Î­ÏÎ¿Ï‡Î·. (My mom is wonderful.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î‘Î¸Î®Î½Î±"
  translation="Athens"
  pronunciation="ah-THEE-nah"
  example="Î˜Î­Î»Î¿Ï…Î¼Îµ Î½Î± Ï€Î¬Î¼Îµ ÏƒÏ„Î·Î½ Î‘Î¸Î®Î½Î± Î¼Î±Î¶Î¯. (We want to go to Athens together.)"
/>

### Group 2: New Sounds, Familiar Shapes

These letters look different but represent sounds you know:

| Greek | Name | Pronunciation | Sound |
|-------|------|---------------|-------|
| **Î’ Î²** | Vita | VEE-tah | V as in "very" (not B!) |
| **Î“ Î³** | Gamma | GHAH-mah | Soft G, like "y" in "yes" before e/i sounds |
| **Î” Î´** | Delta | THEL-tah | TH as in "this" (voiced) |
| **Î— Î·** | Ita | EE-tah | EE as in "see" |
| **Î› Î»** | Lambda | LAHM-thah | L as in "love" |
| **Î  Ï€** | Pi | pee | P as in "pen" |
| **Î¡ Ï** | Rho | roh | Rolled R (like Spanish) |
| **Î£ Ïƒ/Ï‚** | Sigma | SEEG-mah | S as in "sun" |

<VocabCard
  word="Î²Î¹Î²Î»Î¯Î¿"
  translation="book"
  pronunciation="veev-LEE-oh"
  example="Î”Î¹Î±Î²Î¬Î¶Î¿Ï…Î¼Îµ Î­Î½Î± Î²Î¹Î²Î»Î¯Î¿ Î¼Î±Î¶Î¯. (We are reading a book together.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î³Î¬Ï„Î±"
  translation="cat"
  pronunciation="GHAH-tah"
  example="Î— Î³Î¬Ï„Î± Î¼Î±Ï‚ ÎµÎ¯Î½Î±Î¹ Ï€Î¿Î»Ï Î³Î»Ï…ÎºÎ¹Î¬. (Our cat is very sweet.)"
/>

<CultureTip title="The Two Sigmas" flag="ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡·">
Greek has two forms of the lowercase sigma: Ïƒ is used at the beginning or middle of words, while Ï‚ is used only at the end. For example: ÏƒÏ€Î¯Ï„Î¹ (house) ends with Î¹, but ÎšÏÏƒÏ„Î±Ï‚ (Kostas, a name) ends with Ï‚.
</CultureTip>

### Group 3: Unique Greek Sounds

These letters represent sounds that may be new to you:

| Greek | Name | Pronunciation | Sound |
|-------|------|---------------|-------|
| **Î˜ Î¸** | Thita | THEE-tah | TH as in "think" (unvoiced) |
| **Î Î¾** | Xi | ksee | KS as in "box" |
| **Î¦ Ï†** | Fi | fee | F as in "fun" |
| **Î§ Ï‡** | Chi | hee | CH as in Scottish "loch" |
| **Î¨ Ïˆ** | Psi | psee | PS as in "oops" |
| **Î© Ï‰** | Omega | oh-MEH-ghah | O as in "go" (same as omicron in modern Greek) |

<VocabCard
  word="Î¸Î¬Î»Î±ÏƒÏƒÎ±"
  translation="sea"
  pronunciation="THAH-lah-sah"
  example="Î˜Î­Î»Ï‰ Î½Î± ÎºÎ¿Î»Ï…Î¼Ï€Î®ÏƒÎ¿Ï…Î¼Îµ ÏƒÏ„Î· Î¸Î¬Î»Î±ÏƒÏƒÎ±. (I want us to swim in the sea.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ÏˆÏ…Ï‡Î®"
  translation="soul"
  pronunciation="psee-HEE"
  example="Î•Î¯ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Î· ÏˆÏ…Ï‡Î® Î¼Î¿Ï…. (You are my soul.)"
/>

### Group 4: The Tricky Ones

These letters often confuse English speakers because they look like English letters but sound different:

| Greek | Name | Looks Like | Actually Sounds Like |
|-------|------|------------|---------------------|
| **Î¥ Ï…** | Ypsilon | Y/U | EE as in "see" |
| **Î¡ Ï** | Rho | P | Rolled R |
| **Î Î½** | Ni | V | N as in "no" |
| **Î— Î·** | Ita | H | EE as in "see" |
| **Î§ Ï‡** | Chi | X | CH as in "loch" |

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Î£'Î±Î³Î±Ï€Ï"
  translation="I love you"
  pronunciation="sah-ghah-POH"
  context="The most important Greek phrase - now you can read it in Greek script!"
/>

## Common Letter Combinations

Greek has several letter combinations that create distinct sounds. Master these to read fluently:

| Combination | Sound | Example |
|-------------|-------|---------|
| **Î¿Ï…** | "oo" as in "moon" | Î¼Î¿Ï… (moo) - my |
| **Î±Î¹** | "e" as in "pet" | ÎºÎ±Î¹ (keh) - and |
| **ÎµÎ¹** | "ee" as in "see" | ÎµÎ¯ÏƒÎ±Î¹ (EE-seh) - you are |
| **Î¿Î¹** | "ee" as in "see" | Î¼Î¿Î¹ÏÎ¬Î¶Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ (mee-RAH-zoh-meh) - I share |
| **Î¼Ï€** | "b" as in "boy" | Î¼Ï€Î±Î¼Ï€Î¬Ï‚ (bah-BAHS) - dad |
| **Î½Ï„** | "d" as in "dog" | Î½Ï„Î¿Î¼Î¬Ï„Î± (doh-MAH-tah) - tomato |
| **Î³Îº/Î³Î³** | "g" as in "go" | Î±Î³Î³Î»Î¹ÎºÎ¬ (ang-lee-KAH) - English |
| **Ï„Ïƒ** | "ts" as in "cats" | Ï„ÏƒÎ¬Î¹ (TSAH-ee) - tea |
| **Ï„Î¶** | "dz" as in "adze" | Ï„Î¶Î±Ï„Î¶Î¯ÎºÎ¹ (dzah-DZEE-kee) - tzatziki |

<VocabCard
  word="ÎµÏ…Ï‡Î±ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Ï"
  translation="thank you"
  pronunciation="ef-hah-ree-STOH"
  example="Î•Ï…Ï‡Î±ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Ï, Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï…. (Thank you, my love.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î¼Ï€Î¿Ï…ÎºÎ¬Î»Î¹"
  translation="bottle"
  pronunciation="boo-KAH-lee"
  example="Î˜Î­Î»ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Î­Î½Î± Î¼Ï€Î¿Ï…ÎºÎ¬Î»Î¹ ÎºÏÎ±ÏƒÎ¯; (Do you want a bottle of wine?)"
/>

## Romantic Alphabet Practice for Couples

Now let us put your alphabet knowledge to work with romantic vocabulary:

### Love Words A to O

<VocabCard
  word="Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î·"
  translation="love"
  pronunciation="ah-GHAH-pee"
  example="Î— Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï… Î³Î¹Î± ÏƒÎ­Î½Î± ÎµÎ¯Î½Î±Î¹ Î±Î¹ÏÎ½Î¹Î±. (My love for you is eternal.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ÎºÎ±ÏÎ´Î¹Î¬"
  translation="heart"
  pronunciation="kar-THYAH"
  example="Î•Î¯ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Î· ÎºÎ±ÏÎ´Î¹Î¬ Î¼Î¿Ï…. (You are my heart.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ÏŒÎ½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿"
  translation="dream"
  pronunciation="OH-nee-roh"
  example="Î•Î¯ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Ï„Î¿ ÏŒÎ½ÎµÎ¹ÏÏŒ Î¼Î¿Ï…. (You are my dream.)"
/>

### Love Words P to Omega

<VocabCard
  word="Ï†Î¹Î»Î¯"
  translation="kiss"
  pronunciation="fee-LEE"
  example="Î”ÏÏƒÎµ Î¼Î¿Ï… Î­Î½Î± Ï†Î¹Î»Î¯. (Give me a kiss.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ÏˆÏ…Ï‡Î®"
  translation="soul"
  pronunciation="psee-HEE"
  example="Î•Î¯ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Î· ÏˆÏ…Ï‡Î® Î¼Î¿Ï…. (You are my soul.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ï‰ÏÎ±Î¯Î¿Ï‚ / Ï‰ÏÎ±Î¯Î±"
  translation="beautiful/handsome"
  pronunciation="oh-REH-os / oh-REH-ah"
  example="Î•Î¯ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Ï„ÏŒÏƒÎ¿ Ï‰ÏÎ±Î¯Î± Î±Ï€ÏŒÏˆÎµ. (You look so beautiful tonight.)"
/>

## Practice Exercises for Couples

### Exercise 1: Letter Recognition Game

Take turns pointing to random Greek letters and having your partner name them. Keep score and celebrate victories with a kiss!

### Exercise 2: Read These Love Words Together

Practice reading these romantic words aloud:
1. **Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î·** (love)
2. **ÎºÎ±ÏÎ´Î¹Î¬** (heart)
3. **Ï†Î¹Î»Î¯** (kiss)
4. **Î¼Î±Î¶Î¯** (together)
5. **Ï€Î¬Î½Ï„Î±** (always)

### Exercise 3: Write Love Notes

Try writing simple messages to each other using the Greek alphabet:
- **Î£'Î±Î³Î±Ï€Ï** (I love you)
- **ÎœÎ¿Ï… Î»ÎµÎ¯Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ï‚** (I miss you)
- **Î•Î¯ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Ï…Ï€Î­ÏÎ¿Ï‡Î·/Ï…Ï€Î­ÏÎ¿Ï‡Î¿Ï‚** (You are wonderful)

### Exercise 4: Daily Alphabet Challenge

Each day, learn one new Greek word together that starts with the next letter of the alphabet. By the end of a month, you will have built a solid vocabulary foundation!

<CultureTip title="Greek Letters in Science and Math" flag="ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡·">
You already know some Greek letters! Alpha (Î±), beta (Î²), gamma (Î³), delta (Î”), pi (Ï€), and omega (Î©) are used in mathematics and science. This prior familiarity will help you learn faster.
</CultureTip>

## Quick Reference: The Complete Greek Alphabet

| # | Upper | Lower | Name | Sound |
|---|-------|-------|------|-------|
| 1 | Î‘ | Î± | Alpha | ah |
| 2 | Î’ | Î² | Vita | v |
| 3 | Î“ | Î³ | Gamma | gh/y |
| 4 | Î” | Î´ | Delta | th (voiced) |
| 5 | Î• | Îµ | Epsilon | eh |
| 6 | Î– | Î¶ | Zeta | z |
| 7 | Î— | Î· | Ita | ee |
| 8 | Î˜ | Î¸ | Thita | th (unvoiced) |
| 9 | Î™ | Î¹ | Iota | ee |
| 10 | Îš | Îº | Kappa | k |
| 11 | Î› | Î» | Lambda | l |
| 12 | Îœ | Î¼ | Mi | m |
| 13 | Î | Î½ | Ni | n |
| 14 | Î | Î¾ | Xi | ks |
| 15 | ÎŸ | Î¿ | Omicron | o |
| 16 | Î  | Ï€ | Pi | p |
| 17 | Î¡ | Ï | Rho | r (rolled) |
| 18 | Î£ | Ïƒ/Ï‚ | Sigma | s |
| 19 | Î¤ | Ï„ | Tau | t |
| 20 | Î¥ | Ï… | Ypsilon | ee |
| 21 | Î¦ | Ï† | Fi | f |
| 22 | Î§ | Ï‡ | Chi | ch (as in loch) |
| 23 | Î¨ | Ïˆ | Psi | ps |
| 24 | Î© | Ï‰ | Omega | o |

## Tips for Success

1. **Practice daily** - Even 10 minutes a day together makes a difference
2. **Write by hand** - Writing the letters helps cement them in memory
3. **Read everything** - Try to read Greek signs, menus, and social media posts
4. **Be patient** - The alphabet takes most couples 2-3 weeks to master
5. **Make it romantic** - Write love notes to each other in Greek script


Mastering the Greek alphabet together is a beautiful milestone in your language learning journey. Once you can read Greek script, a whole new world opens up - from reading love poems to understanding the signs in Greece to writing secret messages to each other.

Take your time, support each other, and celebrate every small victory. Before you know it, you will be reading **Î£'Î±Î³Î±Ï€Ï** as naturally as "I love you."
